clueweb22-en0030-35-00577.point_content: The pandemic has dramatically changed Americans' personal lives, with 89% mentioning at least one negative change and 73% mentioning at least one positive change.
spans: The vast majority of Americans (89%) mentioned at least one negative change in their own lives, while a smaller share (though still a 73% majority) mentioned at least one unexpected upside.

clueweb22-en0030-35-00577.point_content: The pandemic affected relationships with isolation and missing loved ones, but also strengthened bonds for some.
spans: More than any other issue, Americans responded by bringing up how the pandemic has altered their ability to engage with friends and family.

The single-most common category of comments (mentioned by 41% of those who answered the question) centered around missing family and friends and worrying about losing touch with people they used to see in person.

At the same time, a third (33%) of Americans mentioned positive impacts to their relationships, including being able to spend more time with spouses, children or other family members who no longer have to spend their days at work or school.

clueweb22-en0030-35-00577.point_content: The pandemic disrupted routines and limited activities, but also allowed for new hobbies and a slower pace of life.
spans: Nearly a third (32%) of Americans mentioned ways that the pandemic has limited what activities they can engage in or how they otherwise use their free time.

At the same time, roughly a quarter of Americans (26%) used the question as an opportunity to talk about ways their daily lives have improved, in many cases describing a slower pace of life, new hobbies, more time to get things done around the house or the freedom to simply relax in ways that were not possible in the pre-pandemic era.

clueweb22-en0030-35-00577.point_content: The pandemic negatively impacted physical and mental health for many, but some reported positive health changes.
spans: A relatively small share of Americans (14%) mentioned ways in which their own physical or mental health – or the health of people they know – has improved during the pandemic.
By contrast, twice as many Americans (28%) described how the physical or mental health of themselves or the people they care about has degraded as the pandemic has dragged on.

clueweb22-en0030-35-00577.point_content: The pandemic had a mostly negative impact on society and politics, with some noting increased polarization and frustration.
spans: Roughly one-quarter (26%) of these responses pointed to the ways in which our government, political culture or society in general has seemingly degraded over the course of the pandemic.

clueweb22-en0030-35-00577.point_content: Work situations were negatively impacted for many, but some experienced improved work-life balance due to remote work.
spans: Around one-in-five Americans (23%) described how the pandemic has negatively impacted their job or career or those of people they know.
By contrast, just 13% mentioned positive changes to their work situation, typically in the context of being able to work from home.

clueweb22-en0030-35-00577.point_content: Financially, some Americans faced difficulties, while others saved money during the pandemic.
spans: More than one-in-five Americans (22%) mentioned economic difficulties resulting from the pandemic.
By contrast, just 13% mentioned positive financial changes that have resulted due to the pandemic, typically in the context of using the situation as an opportunity to save money.
